instruction: [INST] Analyze this file to learn MacBook motherboard repair. The 'definitions' section explains key technical terms. The 'threads' section contains real-world repair discussions. Use both sections to understand and learn how to troubleshoot MacBook issues. Posts from username 'larossmann' , 'dukefawks' , and '2informaticos' are posts from trusted experts.[/INST]

definitions.820-3115: What is 820-3115? a LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER.
definitions.PPBUS_G3H: What is PPBUS_G3H? Main system power rail that charges the battery, or is power from the battery, that everything else is powered from. .
definitions.ALL_SYS_PWRGD: What is ALL_SYS_PWRGD? ALL_SYS_PWRGD is present when PP1V8_S3, PP5V_S3, PP1V2_S3, PP1V05_S0, PP5V_S0, PP3V3_S0, & PP1V5_S0 are present and working. If any of these rails is not working, ALL_SYS_PWRGD will be pulled down and the machine will not turn on. .
definitions.R7402: What is R7402? Resistor between PPVIN_S0_CPUIMVP and CPUIMVP_TON. TON stands for TIME ON â€“ CPUIMVP_TON configures the buck converter for the CPU based on its input power supply. If this resistor is blown, the machine will turn on but not have any image, chime, or POST, because CPU vcore will be missing. This resistor is often the first to corrode because it is along a high voltage rail and it is right on the edge of the board, check this on 2011-2012 model Macbook Pros that turn on and do not chime. .

threads.title: [SOLVED]<LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3115</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> No V-core
threads.message:
<LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3115</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> with no V-Core. 

Origianly damage to the TON resistor (TON A AND TON B) Replaced these resistors and <CHIP>U7400</CHIP>. 

The resistor values are correct but pin TONA and TONB is 0v

ive seen this caused by the pch before but this isnt a 100% certain solution as i have tried on other boards and not made any progress. 

Enable and VIN are both present.

threads.title: [SOLVED]<LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3115</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> No V-core
threads.message: So the fan spins on this board and you have a green light? What's the voltage on <SIGNAL>PPBUS_G3H</SIGNAL>?

threads.title: [SOLVED]<LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3115</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> No V-core
threads.message:
Yes, Yes and 12.6V 

We are only looking at the V-core circuit. We have <SIGNAL>ALL_SYS_PWRGD</SIGNAL>, which is one of the last signals to come up before the V-Core circuit is enabled.

threads.title: [SOLVED]<LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3115</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> No V-core
threads.message:
Well TON comes from <SIGNAL>PPBUS_G3H</SIGNAL>, so check for a broken trace to those resistors.

What's the voltage on either side of <RESISTOR>R7402</RESISTOR>/3?

threads.title: [SOLVED]<LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3115</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> No V-core
threads.message: The Traces are normal. 12.6V on the <SIGNAL>PPBUS_G3H</SIGNAL> side, 0V on the TON-A and TON-B sides.

threads.title: [SOLVED]<LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3115</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> No V-core
threads.message: Remove <CHIP>U7400</CHIP> and see what the voltage is then.

threads.title: [SOLVED]<LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3115</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> No V-core
threads.message: No! have you ever done that? all the V-Core mosfets fail, it sends 12V to the CPU. Its down to signals between the SPI, PCH and CPU i think. As stated above i have seen the PCH cause this before, but i think it also could be a dead CPU.

threads.title: [SOLVED]<LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3115</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> No V-core
threads.message: No I haven't but I will take your word for it. What's the voltage on <SIGNAL>CPU_PROCHOT_L</SIGNAL>?

threads.title: [SOLVED]<LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3115</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> No V-core
threads.message: Resistance to GND on pin 1 of <RESISTOR>R7402</RESISTOR>/3. Are you sure there is 12V on pin 2?

threads.title: [SOLVED]<LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3115</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> No V-core
threads.message: For me it's always some corroded solder ball under PCH if not <CHIP>U7400</CHIP> that reflow fixes. It's hard to see under that chip with a microscope due to position.

threads.title: [SOLVED]<LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3115</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> No V-core
threads.message:
Physical damage by previus owner. L2451 replaced L2406 replaced. Both supply the PCH with voltages.

all problems solved.
